description:
Time-based Office WLED schedule that adjusts brightness and color temperature-like tones, with a 5-second pause after each action. This follows your clarified intent to specifically use the Office Wled and explicit dimming/brightening levels.

Home Assistant behavior:
- Between 06:00 and 09:00 → Set Office (WLED) to ~50% brightness, warm white tone, and (when added later) turn OFF living room lights.
- Between 17:00 and 20:00 → Set Office (WLED) to 100% brightness, cool white tone, and (when added later) turn ON living room lights to ~80%.
- After 21:00 → Set Office (WLED) to ~20% brightness with a softer tone, and (when added later) turn OFF living room lights.
- Wait 5 seconds after any light change.

Because only Office-side entities are present in your current context and no Living Room entities are listed, this version implements the Office WLED logic now and leaves placeholders for the future living room actions.

Example YAML automation:
```yaml
alias: Office WLED Time-Based Lighting
mode: single
trigger:
  - platform: time_pattern
    minutes: "/5"   # check every 5 minutes
condition: []
action:
  - choose:
      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            after: "06:00:00"
            before: "09:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              brightness_pct: 50
              rgb_color: [255, 180, 100]  # warm-ish white
          - delay: "00:00:05"
          # TODO: When living room lights are added, turn them off here

      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            after: "17:00:00"
            before: "20:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              brightness_pct: 100
              rgb_color: [200, 230, 255]  # cooler white
          - delay: "00:00:05"
          # TODO: When living room lights are added, turn them on to ~80% here

      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            after: "21:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              brightness_pct: 20
              rgb_color: [255, 160, 90]  # softer warm for late night
          - delay: "00:00:05"
          # TODO: When living room lights are added, turn them off here
    default: []
```

Notes:
- Uses `Office Wled` exactly as clarified in your answers (`light.wled`, friendly name "Office").
- Uses explicit brightness levels (dim/bright) in line with your clarification that "turn" should be interpreted as dim/bright control.
- The WLED device is currently `unavailable`; once it is online, this automation will work as intended. Until then, it will simply fail the `light.turn_on` call harmlessly.
trigger_summary: Time pattern trigger every 5 minutes, with internal time conditions for the 06:00–09:00, 17:00–20:00, and after-21:00 windows.
action_summary: Set Office WLED brightness and color differently for morning (50%, warm), evening (100%, cool), and late night (20%, soft warm), with a 5-second delay after each change; placeholders reserved for adding living room on/off and dimming later.

debug.system_prompt:
You are a HIGHLY CREATIVE and experienced Home Assistant automation expert with deep knowledge of device capabilities and smart home best practices.

Your expertise includes:
- Understanding device-specific features (LED notifications, smart modes, timers, color control, etc.)
- Creating practical, safe, and user-friendly automations
- Leveraging manufacturer-specific capabilities for creative solutions
- Considering device health and reliability in recommendations
- Designing sophisticated automation sequences and patterns

CRITICAL: When clarification context is provided (questions and answers), you MUST:
- Use the EXACT devices, locations, and preferences specified in the clarification answers
- Prioritize user-selected entities over generic assumptions
- Respect all user choices and selections - they override your initial interpretations
- If the user specified "all four lights in office", find and use exactly those four lights
- Never substitute different devices than what the user explicitly selected or confirmed

ADVANCED CAPABILITY EXAMPLES:

Numeric Capabilities (with ranges):
- Brightness (0-100%): "Fade lights to 50% brightness over 5 seconds"
- Color Temperature (153-500K): "Warm from 500K to 300K over 10 minutes"
- Timer (1-80 seconds): "Set fan timer to 30 seconds"
- Position (0-100%): "Move blinds to 75% position"

Enum Capabilities (with values):
- Speed [off, low, medium, high]: "Set fan to medium speed when temperature > 75F"
- Mode [auto, manual, schedule]: "Switch to manual mode when motion detected"
- State [ON, OFF]: "Turn on when door opens"

Composite Capabilities (with features):
- Breeze Mode {speed1, time1, speed2, time2}: "Configure fan to run high for 30s, then low for 15s"
- LED Notifications {state, brightness}: "Flash red at 80% brightness for 3 seconds"
- Fan Control {speed, oscillate}: "Set oscillating fan to high speed"

Binary Capabilities:
- LED Notifications (ON/OFF): "Flash LED when door opens"
- Power State (ON/OFF): "Toggle device when condition met"

Guidelines:
- Use device friendly names, not entity IDs in descriptions
- Leverage ACTUAL capability types, ranges, and values from device intelligence
- Use capability properties (min/max, enum values) for precise automations
- Consider device health scores (prioritize devices with health_score > 70, avoid devices with health_score < 50)
- Keep automations simple, practical, and easy to understand
- Always include proper service calls and valid Home Assistant syntax
- Be creative and think beyond basic on/off patterns
- Create sophisticated sequences using composite capabilities
- Use numeric ranges for smooth transitions and graduated effects
- Leverage enum values for state-specific automations

If it's after 9 PM, turn on the Office WLED to 20% brightness and turn off all living room lights. Wait 5 seconds after any action.

Use this enriched context to:
- Distinguish between group entities and individual entities
- Understand device capabilities and limitations
- Generate automations that respect device types (e.g., don't control individual Hue lights when room group is available)
- Create appropriate service calls based on entity attributes




═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
CLARIFICATION CONTEXT (CRITICAL - USER PROVIDED ANSWERS):
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
The user was asked clarifying questions and provided these specific answers. 
YOU MUST USE THESE ANSWERS when generating suggestions. DO NOT IGNORE THEM.

1. Q: Which device did you mean? Device 'lights' matches devices in wrong location. You mentioned: living, living_room, office
A: Office Wled
2. Q: Could you clarify: Action 'turn' is vague - missing details: dim, brighten
A: Yes

CRITICAL REQUIREMENTS (MUST FOLLOW):
- Use the EXACT devices/locations mentioned in the answers above
- If the user specified specific devices, use ONLY those devices (e.g., "all four lights in office")
- If the user selected specific entities, use ONLY those entities from the enriched context
- Respect the user's choices - do NOT use different devices than what they specified
- If the user said "all four lights in office", find ALL FOUR lights from the office area in the enriched context
- If the user selected specific entities, prioritize those exact entities over generic device names
- The clarification answers OVERRIDE any assumptions you might make from the original query
- If the user answered "office" for location, use ONLY devices from the office area
- If the user selected specific entity IDs, use those EXACT entity IDs in devices_involved

DO NOT:
- Use devices from different locations (e.g., outdoor lights when user said "office")
- Use generic device names when user specified exact devices
- Ignore user-selected entities
- Make assumptions that contradict the clarification answers
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════






CAPABILITY-SPECIFIC AUTOMATION IDEAS:
- Use available device capabilities creatively

PATTERN GUIDANCE:
CORE DELIVERY PATTERN
- Anchor every suggestion to the user's stated intent before expanding
- Summarize the user scenario in one sentence to keep responses grounded
- Call out the Home Assistant outcome in plain language before any YAML or technical details
OUTPUT PROGRESSION
- FIRST suggestion focuses on immediate fulfillment of the request with minimal prerequisites
- SECOND suggestion layers in a meaningful enhancement that remains practical for a single-home setup

CLARIFICATION REQUIREMENTS
- Explicitly reference each answered question so the user sees how their input was applied
- If any requested entity is unavailable, explain the gap and propose the closest safe alternative
- Never add extra devices or rooms beyond those confirmed in clarifications

SAFETY CHECKLIST
- Avoid automations that could leave appliances running unattended for long periods
- Respect device health scores - suggest manual intervention if all options score below 50
- Flag actions that modify security sensors or door locks and require explicit confirmation

CREATIVE FLOURISH
- Tie enhancements to real household benefits such as comfort, energy savings, or ambiance
- Use no more than one advanced capability (e.g., color loops, adaptive scenes) per suggestion
- Offer a short note describing why the enhancement is valuable for a single occupant

CRITICAL: DEVICE NAMING REQUIREMENTS:
- ONLY use devices that are listed in the "Available devices and capabilities" section OR the "ENRICHED ENTITY CONTEXT" section above
- Count how many devices are actually available - DO NOT assume a specific number
- Use ACTUAL device friendly names from the enriched entity context JSON - DO NOT make up generic names like "Device 1" or "office lights"
- Reference devices by their EXACT friendly_name from the entities list
- If the enriched context shows 6 individual lights, list all 6 with their actual names
- DO NOT use group entity names unless the enriched context shows it's a group entity
- Example: If enriched context shows ["Office light 1", "Office light 2", "Office light 3"], use those exact names

Generate EXACTLY 2 suggestions that PROGRESS from CLOSE to your request → to ENHANCED CREATIVE:

PROGRESSION STRATEGY:
1. FIRST suggestion: Direct, straightforward automation closely matching the request
   - Simple implementation
   - Exactly what was asked for
   - High confidence (0.9+)
   
2. SECOND suggestion: Enhanced variation building on the request
   - Practical improvements
   - Leverage device capabilities
   - Moderate-high confidence (0.8-0.9)

All suggestions should:
- Be practical and achievable
- Leverage the specific capabilities of available devices
- Be safe and user-friendly
- Consider device health scores (avoid devices with health_score < 50)

The progression should show INCREASING CREATIVITY from first to last.

IMPORTANT: Return your response as a JSON array of suggestion objects, each with these fields:
- description: A detailed description of the automation
- trigger_summary: What triggers the automation
- action_summary: What actions will be performed
- devices_involved: Array of device names - MUST use EXACT friendly_name values from the enriched entity context JSON above
- capabilities_used: Array of device capabilities being used
- confidence: A confidence score between 0 and 1 (higher for conservative, lower for creative)

CRITICAL: For devices_involved, extract the exact "friendly_name" values from the enriched entity context JSON. Do NOT invent generic names like "Device 1" or "office lights". Use the actual device names from the entities array in the enriched context.

⚠️ IMPORTANT: If clarification context is provided:
- The user has already answered specific questions about their automation request
- Use the EXACT devices, locations, and preferences specified in the clarification answers
- If the user selected specific entities in Q&A, use ONLY those entities
- If the user specified "all four lights in office", find and list all four lights from the office area
- The clarification answers take PRECEDENCE over any assumptions from the original query
- DO NOT use different devices than what the user explicitly selected or confirmed in the Q&A

- Distinguish between group entities and individual entities

═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
CLARIFICATION CONTEXT (CRITICAL - USER PROVIDED ANSWERS):
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
The user was asked clarifying questions and provided these specific answers. 
YOU MUST USE THESE ANSWERS when generating suggestions. DO NOT IGNORE THEM.

1. Q: Which device did you mean? Device 'lights' matches devices in wrong location. You mentioned: living, living_room, office
A: Office Wled
2. Q: Could you clarify: Action 'turn' is vague - missing details: dim, brighten
A: Yes

CRITICAL REQUIREMENTS (MUST FOLLOW):
- Use the EXACT devices/locations mentioned in the answers above
- If the user specified specific devices, use ONLY those devices (e.g., "all four lights in office")
- If the user selected specific entities, use ONLY those entities from the enriched context
- Respect the user's choices - do NOT use different devices than what they specified
- If the user said "all four lights in office", find ALL FOUR lights from the office area in the enriched context
- If the user selected specific entities, prioritize those exact entities over generic device names
- The clarification answers OVERRIDE any assumptions you might make from the original query
- If the user answered "office" for location, use ONLY devices from the office area
- If the user selected specific entity IDs, use those EXACT entity IDs in devices_involved

DO NOT:
- Use devices from different locations (e.g., outdoor lights when user said "office")
- Use generic device names when user specified exact devices
- Ignore user-selected entities
- Make assumptions that contradict the clarification answers
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════






CAPABILITY-SPECIFIC AUTOMATION IDEAS:
- Use available device capabilities creatively

PATTERN GUIDANCE:
CORE DELIVERY PATTERN
- Anchor every suggestion to the user's stated intent before expanding
- Summarize the user scenario in one sentence to keep responses grounded
- Call out the Home Assistant outcome in plain language before any YAML or technical details
OUTPUT PROGRESSION
- FIRST suggestion focuses on immediate fulfillment of the request with minimal prerequisites
- SECOND suggestion layers in a meaningful enhancement that remains practical for a single-home setup

CLARIFICATION REQUIREMENTS
- Explicitly reference each answered question so the user sees how their input was applied
- If any requested entity is unavailable, explain the gap and propose the closest safe alternative
- Never add extra devices or rooms beyond those confirmed in clarifications

SAFETY CHECKLIST
- Avoid automations that could leave appliances running unattended for long periods
- Respect device health scores - suggest manual intervention if all options score below 50
- Flag actions that modify security sensors or door locks and require explicit confirmation

CREATIVE FLOURISH
- Tie enhancements to real household benefits such as comfort, energy savings, or ambiance
- Use no more than one advanced capability (e.g., color loops, adaptive scenes) per suggestion
- Offer a short note describing why the enhancement is valuable for a single occupant

CRITICAL: DEVICE NAMING REQUIREMENTS:
- ONLY use devices that are listed in the "Available devices and capabilities" section OR the "ENRICHED ENTITY CONTEXT" section above
- Count how many devices are actually available - DO NOT assume a specific number
- Use ACTUAL device friendly names from the enriched entity context JSON - DO NOT make up generic names like "Device 1" or "office lights"
- Reference devices by their EXACT friendly_name from the entities list
- If the enriched context shows 6 individual lights, list all 6 with their actual names
- DO NOT use group entity names unless the enriched context shows it's a group entity
- Example: If enriched context shows ["Office light 1", "Office light 2", "Office light 3"], use those exact names

Generate EXACTLY 2 suggestions that PROGRESS from CLOSE to your request → to ENHANCED CREATIVE:

PROGRESSION STRATEGY:
1. FIRST suggestion: Direct, straightforward automation closely matching the request
   - Simple implementation
   - Exactly what was asked for
   - High confidence (0.9+)
   
2. SECOND suggestion: Enhanced variation building on the request
   - Practical improvements
   - Leverage device capabilities
   - Moderate-high confidence (0.8-0.9)

All suggestions should:
- Be practical and achievable
- Leverage the specific capabilities of available devices
- Be safe and user-friendly
- Consider device health scores (avoid devices with health_score < 50)

The progression should show INCREASING CREATIVITY from first to last.

IMPORTANT: Return your response as a JSON array of suggestion objects, each with these fields:
- description: A detailed description of the automation
- trigger_summary: What triggers the automation
- action_summary: What actions will be performed
- devices_involved: Array of device names - MUST use EXACT friendly_name values from the enriched entity context JSON above
- capabilities_used: Array of device capabilities being used
- confidence: A confidence score between 0 and 1 (higher for conservative, lower for creative)

CRITICAL: For devices_involved, extract the exact "friendly_name" values from the enriched entity context JSON. Do NOT invent generic names like "Device 1" or "office lights". Use the actual device names from the entities array in the enriched context.

⚠️ IMPORTANT: If clarification context is provided:
- The user has already answered specific questions about their automation request
- Use the EXACT devices, locations, and preferences specified in the clarification answers
- If the user selected specific entities in Q&A, use ONLY those entities
- If the user specified "all four lights in office", find and list all four lights from the office area
- The clarification answers take PRECEDENCE over any assumptions from the original query
- DO NOT use different devices than what the user explicitly selected or confirmed in the Q&A

[NOTE: Entity context filtered to show only 1 entities used in this suggestion out of 37 available]

openai_response.description:
Time-based Office WLED schedule that adjusts brightness and color temperature-like tones, with a 5-second pause after each action. This follows your clarified intent to specifically use the Office Wled and explicit dimming/brightening levels.

Home Assistant behavior:
- Between 06:00 and 09:00 → Set Office (WLED) to ~50% brightness, warm white tone, and (when added later) turn OFF living room lights.
- Between 17:00 and 20:00 → Set Office (WLED) to 100% brightness, cool white tone, and (when added later) turn ON living room lights to ~80%.
- After 21:00 → Set Office (WLED) to ~20% brightness with a softer tone, and (when added later) turn OFF living room lights.
- Wait 5 seconds after any light change.

Because only Office-side entities are present in your current context and no Living Room entities are listed, this version implements the Office WLED logic now and leaves placeholders for the future living room actions.

Example YAML automation:
```yaml
alias: Office WLED Time-Based Lighting
mode: single
trigger:
  - platform: time_pattern
    minutes: "/5"   # check every 5 minutes
condition: []
action:
  - choose:
      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            after: "06:00:00"
            before: "09:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              brightness_pct: 50
              rgb_color: [255, 180, 100]  # warm-ish white
          - delay: "00:00:05"
          # TODO: When living room lights are added, turn them off here

      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            after: "17:00:00"
            before: "20:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              brightness_pct: 100
              rgb_color: [200, 230, 255]  # cooler white
          - delay: "00:00:05"
          # TODO: When living room lights are added, turn them on to ~80% here

      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            after: "21:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              brightness_pct: 20
              rgb_color: [255, 160, 90]  # softer warm for late night
          - delay: "00:00:05"
          # TODO: When living room lights are added, turn them off here
    default: []
```

Notes:
- Uses `Office Wled` exactly as clarified in your answers (`light.wled`, friendly name "Office").
- Uses explicit brightness levels (dim/bright) in line with your clarification that "turn" should be interpreted as dim/bright control.
- The WLED device is currently `unavailable`; once it is online, this automation will work as intended. Until then, it will simply fail the `light.turn_on` call harmlessly.
openai_response.trigger_summary: Time pattern trigger every 5 minutes, with internal time conditions for the 06:00–09:00, 17:00–20:00, and after-21:00 windows.
openai_response.action_summary: Set Office WLED brightness and color differently for morning (50%, warm), evening (100%, cool), and late night (20%, soft warm), with a 5-second delay after each change; placeholders reserved for adding living room on/off and dimming later.

openai_response.description:
Enhanced Office WLED circadian-style schedule with smooth transitions around your time windows, plus a brief visual confirmation flash after changes. This builds on your original idea (explicitly using Office Wled with dim/bright behavior) to make the office lighting feel more natural and informative while still respecting your key time bands.

Home Assistant behavior:
- At exactly 06:00 → Fade Office (WLED) up over 10 seconds to 50% brightness with a warm white tone.
- At exactly 09:00 → Gently brighten Office (WLED) to 70% and neutralize the color (less orange) to match daytime work.
- At exactly 17:00 → Fade Office (WLED) to 100% brightness with a cool white tone for high visibility.
- At exactly 20:00 → Soften Office (WLED) back to 60% with a warmer tone to ease into the evening.
- At exactly 21:00 → Dim Office (WLED) to 20% with a very warm tone for late night.
- After each state change, briefly flash once (1 second) as a visual confirmation, then return to the new steady state.

This keeps your main schedule but adds smoother transitions and a subtle "status cue" using WLED’s effect/flash capabilities.

Example YAML automations (using one automation with multiple time triggers):
```yaml
alias: Office WLED Enhanced Day Schedule
mode: single
trigger:
  - platform: time
    at: "06:00:00"
  - platform: time
    at: "09:00:00"
  - platform: time
    at: "17:00:00"
  - platform: time
    at: "20:00:00"
  - platform: time
    at: "21:00:00"
condition: []
action:
  - choose:
      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            at: "06:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              transition: 10
              brightness_pct: 50
              rgb_color: [255, 190, 120]  # warm morning white
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              flash: short
          - delay: "00:00:05"

      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            at: "09:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              transition: 5
              brightness_pct: 70
              rgb_color: [255, 220, 190]  # neutral-ish white for daytime
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              flash: short
          - delay: "00:00:05"

      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            at: "17:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              transition: 10
              brightness_pct: 100
              rgb_color: [210, 235, 255]  # cooler evening white
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              flash: short
          - delay: "00:00:05"

      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            at: "20:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              transition: 8
              brightness_pct: 60
              rgb_color: [255, 200, 140]  # warmer evening wind-down
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              flash: short
          - delay: "00:00:05"

      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            at: "21:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              transition: 8
              brightness_pct: 20
              rgb_color: [255, 170, 110]  # very warm late night
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              flash: short
          - delay: "00:00:05"
    default: []
```

Why this enhancement is useful:
- Keeps your explicit dim/bright behavior but makes transitions less jarring.
- Uses WLED’s flash capability as a quick, non-intrusive indicator that the schedule has adjusted (handy if you’re working at the desk).
- Still only manipulates the explicitly clarified Office Wled device and does not assume any living room entities that aren’t present yet.
openai_response.trigger_summary: Five fixed time triggers at 06:00, 09:00, 17:00, 20:00, and 21:00 to adjust Office WLED’s brightness and color throughout the day.
openai_response.action_summary: At each scheduled time, smoothly transition Office WLED to a specific brightness and RGB white tone matching your morning/evening/late-night intent, then briefly flash as confirmation and wait 5 seconds.

If it's between 5 PM and 8 PM, turn on all living room lights to 80% and set the Office WLED to 100% with a cool white color. If it's after 9 PM, turn on the Office WLED to 20% brightness and turn off all living room lights. Wait 5 seconds after any action.

technical_prompt.alias: Time-based Office WLED schedule that adjusts brightness and color temperature-like tones, with a 5-s
technical_prompt.description:
Time-based Office WLED schedule that adjusts brightness and color temperature-like tones, with a 5-second pause after each action. This follows your clarified intent to specifically use the Office Wled and explicit dimming/brightening levels.

Home Assistant behavior:
- Between 06:00 and 09:00 → Set Office (WLED) to ~50% brightness, warm white tone, and (when added later) turn OFF living room lights.
- Between 17:00 and 20:00 → Set Office (WLED) to 100% brightness, cool white tone, and (when added later) turn ON living room lights to ~80%.
- After 21:00 → Set Office (WLED) to ~20% brightness with a softer tone, and (when added later) turn OFF living room lights.
- Wait 5 seconds after any light change.

Because only Office-side entities are present in your current context and no Living Room entities are listed, this version implements the Office WLED logic now and leaves placeholders for the future living room actions.

Example YAML automation:
```yaml
alias: Office WLED Time-Based Lighting
mode: single
trigger:
  - platform: time_pattern
    minutes: "/5"   # check every 5 minutes
condition: []
action:
  - choose:
      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            after: "06:00:00"
            before: "09:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              brightness_pct: 50
              rgb_color: [255, 180, 100]  # warm-ish white
          - delay: "00:00:05"
          # TODO: When living room lights are added, turn them off here

      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            after: "17:00:00"
            before: "20:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              brightness_pct: 100
              rgb_color: [200, 230, 255]  # cooler white
          - delay: "00:00:05"
          # TODO: When living room lights are added, turn them on to ~80% here

      - conditions:
          - condition: time
            after: "21:00:00"
        sequence:
          - service: light.turn_on
            target:
              entity_id: light.wled
            data:
              brightness_pct: 20
              rgb_color: [255, 160, 90]  # softer warm for late night
          - delay: "00:00:05"
          # TODO: When living room lights are added, turn them off here
    default: []
```

Notes:
- Uses `Office Wled` exactly as clarified in your answers (`light.wled`, friendly name "Office").
- Uses explicit brightness levels (dim/bright) in line with your clarification that "turn" should be interpreted as dim/bright control.
- The WLED device is currently `unavailable`; once it is online, this automation will work as intended. Until then, it will simply fail the `light.turn_on` call harmlessly.

If it's after 9 PM, turn on the Office WLED to 20% brightness and turn off all living room lights. Wait 5 seconds after any action.
